header_summary:
Ava Chow announced the availability of Bitcoin Core version v28.1rc1 release candidate binaries for community testing, alongside the source code on GitHub. This version introduces updates, fixes, and enhancements detailed in the preliminary release notes, aiming for stability and reliability before its final release. Community engagement in testing is crucial for the identification of any remaining issues. The binaries and source code can be accessed through [Bitcoin Core's official website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.1/test.rc1/) and [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v28.1rc1), respectively.

Marathon-gary's discussion explores the concept of miners acting as Managed Service Providers (MSPs) to avoid fees using Discreet Log Contracts (DLCs), raising questions about the financial and operational implications of such a model. This approach suggests miners could manage operations more cost-effectively, albeit with upfront capital investment. The conversation seeks to understand the specific fees being circumvented and the feasibility of this strategy, detailed further at [DelvingBitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/radpool-decentralised-mining-pool-with-futures-contracts-for-payouts/1262/18).

SCrypt-ts developed a smart contract for Bitcoin, akin to the hashrate escrow mechanism in Drivechain but without requiring major protocol upgrades. This contract uses OP_CAT for sidechain covenants, allowing BTC transfer between the Bitcoin mainchain and sidechains without altering the mainchain's structure. This innovation, detailed on [GitHub](https://github.com/sCrypt-Inc/cat-contracts/blob/master/src/contracts/driveChain.ts), represents a significant step in enhancing Bitcoin's functionality through smart contracts and decentralized consensus without core protocol changes.

Securitybrahh's discussion highlights skepticism towards Monero and concerns over Bitcoin's role as cash, emphasizing the need for digital assets like Lightning Network or Monero to fill this gap. The debate touches on Bitcoin's fungibility issues and explores technical solutions like CTV and OP_CAT for transaction pools, aiming to enhance Bitcoin's scalability, privacy, and utility as digital cash. This nuanced view of the cryptocurrency landscape distinguishes Bitcoin's value retention from Monero's suitability for everyday transactions due to its privacy features, with further insights available through linked discussions at [DelvingBitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/op-cat-vs-op-ctv-vs-xmr/1303).

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.1 Release Candidate 1 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.1rc1 release candidate binaries are now accessible for community testing.
- The source code and preliminary release notes are available on GitHub, detailing new features and fixes.
- This release aims to identify and address any remaining issues before the final v28.1 version is officially released.

recent_posts.title: Radpool: Decentralised Mining Pool With Futures Contracts For Payouts
recent_posts.summary:
- Miners operating as MSPs could avoid fees through upfront investment.
- The strategy leads to questions on the viability of miners holding valueless DLCs.
- Clarification on the "fees" avoided in the MSP model is sought for deeper understanding.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin OP_CAT Use Cases Series #5: Drivechain
recent_posts.summary:
- A smart contract enables sidechains on Bitcoin without major updates using OP_CAT.
- The contract uses miner voting for withdrawals, emphasizing decentralized consensus.
- The technology, inspired by Bitcoin Cash's SHA-gate, is detailed on GitHub for public access.

recent_posts.title: op_CAT vs op_CTV vs XMR
recent_posts.summary:
- Skepticism exists towards Monero and Bitcoin's ability to act as cash, filling a gap.
- Monero is preferred due to its fungibility and privacy advantages over Bitcoin.
- Technical insights on enhancing Bitcoin, like CTV and transaction pools, are discussed for utility improvement.

active_posts.title: Un-FE’d Covenants: Char-ting a new path to Emulated Covenants via BitVM Integrity Checks
active_posts.summary:
- The email introduces an innovative Bitcoin covenant implementation that avoids protocol changes.
- It discusses covenant emulation via emulators, signing servers, and financial penalties for rule breaches.
- A detailed paper on this approach is accessible online, providing comprehensive insights.

active_posts.title: Covenants Support - Bitcoin Wiki
active_posts.summary:
- A new initiative collects Bitcoin developers' opinions on covenant proposals via a draft wiki page.
- The initiative, resembling the SegWit support approach, aims for consensus on soft forks.
- Developers can contribute by adding opcodes and insights, with a focus on OP_CTV's potential benefits.

active_posts.title: Full Disclosure: "Transaction-Relay Throughput Overflow Attacks against Off-Chain Protocols"
active_posts.summary:
- The report identifies a new transaction-relay jamming attack on bitcoin's lightning channels.
- It outlines two attack variants, "high overflow" and "low overflow", affecting the network.
- Mitigation strategies for lightning node operators and developers are proposed in the report.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal highlights Bitcoin protocol vulnerabilities and suggests improvements for network security.
- It addresses specific issues like the timewarp exploit and proposes mitigating legacy transaction risks.
- Community input is encouraged for refining the proposal, which includes both consensus and contentious changes.

active_posts.title: Libbitcoin for Core people
active_posts.summary:
- Eric Voskuil highlighted Libbitcoin's IBD speed is up to 15 times faster than Bitcoin Core.
- Libbitcoin uses an event-based, asynchronous system and relational database for enhanced performance.
- The platform also includes features for omitting certain validations and handling reorganizations efficiently.

active_posts.title: Unspendable keys in descriptors
active_posts.summary:
- The integration of miniscript with taproot in Bitcoin Core enhances wallet development possibilities.
- Generating specific unspendable keys that are secure and practical presents challenges for developers.
- Various methods for creating unspendable keys have trade-offs, necessitating further refinement.

today_in_history_posts.title: Capacity increases for the Bitcoin system.
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Gregory Maxwell discussed Bitcoin's development and scaling at the Hong Kong workshop.
- He advocates for Segregated Witness, enhancing scalability and security without hard forks.
- Proposed innovations aim for efficient scaling, aligning miner and user incentives.

today_in_history_posts.title: GUI for Lightning Network?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Denis Gorbachev inquires about creating a GUI for LN node management in a forum post.
- The forum thread seeks community suggestions for GUI features, emphasizing streamlining node management.
- The discussion remains speculative, with no clear development plans for the GUI disclosed.

today_in_history_posts.title: Merging incomparable linearizations
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Developing optimal blockchain linearizations improves transaction processing efficiency.
- Prefix-intersection merging offers improvements over basic and intersection merging techniques.
- This new method needs a formal efficacy proof, as discussed on a dedicated thread.
